moves.1. d4: this game was drawn against an opponent rated 1707.  black probably had winning chances with a vicious h-file attack.  but against tougher opposition, I was happy to settle for a draw.
moves.1... d5 2. c4 c6 3. cxd5 cxd5 4. Nc3 Nf6: in rather dubious fashion, i retreated the bishop back to g6, where it was captured.  this doubled pawns but allowed me a semi-open h-file: thematic in london system games.
moves.7... Bg6 8. Bxg6 hxg6 9. O-O: not fearing about the h-file pressure, he castles kingside.
moves.9... Bb4: a possible inaccuracy.  the bishop could be a tactical target, and it is not doing anything very useful.  better would have been bd6.
moves.10. Ne5: this move looks unpleasant, but i could not see any concrete threats.  i proceeded to simply exchange knights and relieve the pressure.
moves.10... Nbd7 11. Re1 Nxe5 12. dxe5 Ne4: a strong move.  black was gained the initiative.  his c3 knight is under pressure and can't move without losing the exchange.  white is forced to defend.
moves.13. Bd2 Qh4: the attack suddenly develops.  white must meet the threat of qxh2+, and also the menacing kxf2...
moves.14. Nxe4 Qxh2+ 15. Kf1 Qh1+ 16. Ke2 Qxg2: perhaps qg4+ would have given black better winning chances...
moves.17. Bxb4 Qg4+ 18. f3 Rh2+ 19. Nf2 Qc4+ 2: and here a drawn was agreed upon.  had  i been playing more aggressively, i would have found a way to swing the rook to c8, which could have lead to some winning lines...
